Highlights

Cellular internalization of PAA-TiOx NPs caused increase in H2O2 level in tumor cells  The cellular high level of H2O2 resulted in high efficiency of radiotherapy  Optimal dose of PAA-TiOx NPs was 1 mg/ml with any X-ray irradiation dose

p. 3
Abstract
Polyacrylic acid-modified titanium peroxide nanoparticles (PAA-TiOx NPs) are promising radiosensitizers that
enhance the therapeutic effect of X-ray irradiation after local injection into tumors. However, the mechanism for
this reaction has remained unclear with the exception of the involvement of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), which is released by PAA-TiOx NPs to a liquid phase during dispersion. In the present study, a clonogenic assay was used to compare PAA-TiOx NPs with free H2O2 molecules to investigate the effect exerted on the radiosensitivity of cancer cells in vitro. A cell-free dialysis method revealed that a portion of the H2O2 adsorbed onto the PAA-TiOx NPs during synthesis could be released during a treatment regimen. The H2O2 release lasted for 7 h, which was sufficient for one radiation treatment procedure. For in vitro experiments, cultured human pancreatic cancer cells
took up PAA-TiOx NPs in 10 min after administration. Interestingly, when the cells were washed with a buffer after treatment with either a PAA-TiOx NP or H2O2 solution, the intracellular H2O2 levels remained higher with PAA-TiOx NP treatment compared with the H2O2 solution treatment. Furthermore, the effects of subsequent X-ray irradiation corresponded to the intracellular H2O2 levels. These results indicate that PAA-TiOx NPs are efficient carriers of H2O2 into cancer cells and thus enhance the radiosensitivity.
Keywords Radiotherapy; Titanium oxide nanoparticle; Hydrogen peroxide; radiosensitization; drug delivery system

Introduction
Since the discovery of X-rays, radiotherapy has been a widely used addition to surgical resection and
chemotherapy in the treatment of cancers.[1,2] Radiotherapy embodies both advantages of the other two major
treatment approaches: (i) it has a local therapeutic effect on a tumor, which is similar to surgical resection; and, (ii)
it is physically non-invasive, which is similar to chemotherapy. However, radiotherapy also has various side
effects, which also are similar to those of the alternatives.[3,4] Therefore, a number of studies have developed
improvements in the therapeutic efficacy of radiotherapy.[5–9]
Radiosensitizing therapy is one of the attempts. Radiosensitizing therapy involves the introduction of
radiosensitizing agents into tumors via certain pathways, which enhances the therapeutic effect of subsequent
X-ray irradiation. Many materials have been investigated as radiosensitizer candidates: organic chemicals,[10–
13] proteins,[14–16] and inorganic nanoparticles (NPs).[5,17–20] The underlying premise for the development of
all types of radiosensitizing therapies is that X-ray doses to shrink tumors could be decreased after the
administration of a radiosensitizer. Radiosensitizing therapies could thus be used to treat patients with
high-mortality malignant cancers who have problems withstanding conventional radiotherapy.
Along with other materials, many studies have focused on the use of inorganic NPs as potential
radiosensitizers.[21–23] Gold NPs have been the most extensively investigated in this category[24,25] due to
their radiosensitizing capability, biocompatibility, and amenability to surface modification. Indeed, many reports
have shown that gold NPs could be delivered to tumors via tumor-targeting ligands attached to the NP
surface.[26,27] However, gold NPs have yet to be used as radiosensitizers in clinical practice. Meanwhile, hafnia
NPs (designated ‘NBTXR3’) were recently developed, and currently are undergoing clinical investigation as a
promising radiosensitizing agent.[28] These high atomic number (high-Z) materials strongly interact with X-rays,
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
p. 5
generating secondary electrons and/or specific X-rays that subsequently produce greater amounts of reactive
oxygen species (ROS) than would be produced without a sensitizer. Enhanced ROS production is thought to be
the cause of the damage observed in radiosensitizer-treated cancer cells.
Also, ceramic-based NPs have been investigated for use as radiosensitizers. In addition to NPs composed
entirely of ceramics,[29,30] ceramic nanocomposites incorporated with other heavy metals have also been
evaluated in order to enhance the interaction with X-rays.[31] Titanium dioxide nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) have been extensively studied for bio-applications, which has resulted in their widespread use in the food,[32]
cosmetics,[33] and medical industries.[34] Recent reports have documented the use of TiO2 NPs as radiosensitizers, although titanium is a relatively light element compared with the metal materials mentioned
above. E. Youkhana et al. used a phantom dosimeter and an in vitro cell system in a precise investigation of the
radiosensitizing properties of TiO2 NPs with surface amino groups.[35] W. Pan et al. synthesized TiO2 NPs loaded with a cell cycle arrest agent (SN-38) and additionally modified the surface with transactivator transcription (TAT)
peptides and arginine-glycine-aspartic (RGD) peptides. Those functionalized TiO2 NPs showed effective radiosensitization in vitro and in vivo and proved that TiO2 NPs could serve as radiosensitizers as well as agents for the delivery of a drug cargo.[36]
Polyacrylic acid–modified titanium peroxide (PAA-TiOx) NPs are also considered potential radiosensitizers.
PAA-TiOx NPs are synthesized by reacting PAA-TiO2 NPs with H2O2. The negative charge of PAA that covers the surface monodispersed the TiO2 NPs even in a biological environment such as blood. Surface modification by polyethylene glycol (PEG) is generally used to improve the dispersibility of nanoparticles. In our preliminary
experiments, however, the dispersion stability of PAA-TiOx NPs was higher than that of PEG-TiOx NPs in a saline solution. The dispersibility of NPs is critical for their practical use as a medicine. TiOx is TiO2 treated with H2O2,
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
p. 6
and this has been studied for a long time, although it is not readily available. When the TiO2 surface is treated with H2O2, stable ROS such as superoxide anion radicals (O2•-), peroxide anion (O22-), and hydroperoxide (-OOH) form on the surface and are detected by electron spin resonance (ESR) spectrometry as a result of the adsorption
of H2O2.[37–40] In addition, when H2O2 vapor was adsorbed onto the TiO2-surface, subsequent heating of the sample resulted in the release of O2 rather than H2O2 from the gas-solid interface.[37] We previously revealed that PAA-TiOx NPs release H2O2 during the liquid phase of NP dispersion. No report has shown that H2O2 adsorbed onto the TiO2 surface is released again. Since the released H2O2 was not derived from any photocatalytic reaction, such as the decomposition of water, the H2O2 might have been adsorbed onto the surface of PAA-TiO2 NPs during the synthesis of PAA-TiOx NPs. Thus, investigating the adsorption and desorption characteristics of H2O2 on PAA-TiO2 NPs is one of the objectives of this paper.
In our previous study, the radiosensitizing effect of PAA-TiOx NPs in vivo was investigated in collaboration
with clinical radiologists.[41] A local injection of PAA-TiOx NPs into MIAPaCa-2 (human pancreatic cancer cell line) tumors xenografted to nude mice enhanced the therapeutic effect of radiation treatment. Moreover,
subsequent research revealed that the radiosensitizing mechanism for PAA-TiOx NPs differs from that of other inorganic NPs.[42] In our experiments, PAA-TiOx NPs produced either a minimal amount of ROS or none at all in interactions with X-ray irradiation. Thus, H2O2 release from PAA-TiOx NPs could change the micro environment inside the tumor tissue and enhance its sensitivity to X-ray irradiation. Many reports have actually suggested that
an increase in intracellular H2O2 levels is advantageous for radiotherapy.[43–45] The direct administration of H2O2 into the tumors of cancer patients was clinically investigated in the KORTUC (Kochi Oxydol-Radiation Therapy for
Unresectable Carcinomas) study.[9,46,47] When H2O2 solution was injected directly into the tumor, however, problems persisted, which included rapid diffusion into the surrounding tissues and coincident pain for the patient.

na l P

p. 7
H2O2 molecules easily permeate tissues along with blood flow. Thus, in the present study, we aimed to establish that PAA-TiOx NPs function as effective radiosensitizers by delivering H2O2 inside cancer cells, increasing intracellular H2O2 levels, and promoting the retention of high levels of H2O2. First, the adsorption and desorption properties of H2O2 on PAA-TiO2 NPs were characterized via dialysis (Scheme S1). Additionally, the amount of O2•stabilized on the surface of the PAA-TiO2 NPs on which H2O2 had been adsorbed was calculated using electron spin resonance (ESR) spectrometry in order to establish the mode of H2O2-adsorption on the NPs. Next, we used a human pancreatic cancer cell line in an in vitro investigation to establish whether PAA-TiOx NPs or H2O2 solution would more effectively maintain the high intracellular H2O2 levels that result in efficient radiosensitivity.
Material and methods

sections.heading: Synthesis of nanoparticles
sections.text:
PAA-TiOx NPs were synthesized according to a procedure established in a previous report.[42] Briefly,
PAA-modified titanium dioxide NPs (PAA-TiO2 NPs) were synthesized using commercially obtained TiO2 NPs with a specific surface area of 300 m2/g (Ishihara Sangyo Kaisha, Osaka, Japan) via a hydrothermal method for
surface modification with PAA. PAA-TiOx NPs were synthesized from PAA-TiO2 NPs by immersion in 6% H2O2 solution. The synthesized NPs were confirmed via dynamic light scattering (DLS) and transmission electron
microscope (TEM). DLS was performed using a Zetasizer nano ZS (Malvern Instruments Ltd., Worcestershire,
UK) to measure the diameter and Z-potential of the NPs. We used an NP concentration of 1 mg/ml. A 1 mg/ml
dispersion of PAA-TiOx NPs was applied dropwise onto a copper TEM grid with a polystyrene membrane and then dried at room temperature. TEM observation was performed using a JEM-2100F instrument (JEOL, Tokyo,
Japan).
Jo ur
na l P
re -p

p. 8
Analysis of H2O2 adsorption and release on the surface of PAA-TiO2 NPs
The series of methods described in this section is summarized in Scheme S1. For analysis of H2O2
adsorption, PAA-TiO2 NPs and H2O2 were mixed in Dulbecco’s phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; Nacalai Tesque, Kyoto, Japan) at 1 mg/ml and 1,000 µM, respectively. The mixture was incubated in a rotary incubator at 37 °C
and sampled over time. The free H2O2 in the sampled mixture was separated from the PAA-TiO2 NPs via ultrafiltration, and the H2O2 concentration was measured to quantify the amount of the H2O2 adsorbed onto the NPs. The value of the total amount of H2O2 adsorbed onto the PAA-TiO2 NPs at 72 h after incubation represented the total amount of H2O2 finally adsorbed onto the NPs. For analysis of H2O2 release, 1-ml of the mixture solution where H2O2 was completely adsorbed onto the NPs was packed in a cellulose dialysis tube with a pore size of 50-Å (Viskase Co., Willowbrook, IL, USA). The solution was then dialyzed in a baffled flask filled with 200 ml of
PBS with rotary shaking at 120 rpm and 37 °C. The dialysate was sampled over time to determine the
concentration of the free H2O2 desorbed from PAA-TiO2 NPs. The H2O2-release profile of the PAA-TiOx NPs was determined using the same dialysis method described above. H2O2 concentration measurement was performed using a Hydrogen Peroxide Fluorometric Detection kit (Enzo Life Sciences, Farmingdale, NY, USA). A multi-label
plate reader (Wallac 1420 ARVOsx; Perkin Elmer, Waltham, MA, USA) was employed to measure the
fluorescence at an excitation wavelength (Ex) of 490 nm with an emission wavelength (Em) of 572 nm.
ESR analysis of O2•- adsorbed on the surface of PAA-TiO2 NPs A solution with H2O2 completely adsorbed onto PAA-TiO2 NPs was prepared according to the previous section
and dried under air at room temperature. A residue of approximately 20 mg was placed in a sample tube and

sections.heading: Cytotoxicity assay
sections.text:
Cells were seeded into 96-well plates (in triplicate) at a density of 1 × 104 cells/well. After incubation for 24 h,
cells were attached to NPs at 0.01 to 5 mg/ml for 1, 24, or 48 h. The cells were then washed twice with PBS, and
then 100 μl of fresh medium was added. Next, 3 µl of WST-8 reagent (Cell Counting Kit-8; Dojindo Laboratories,
Kumamoto, Japan) was added to each well, followed by incubation for 1 h at 37 °C. The fluorescence of FITC
(Ex: 488 nm/Em: 505 nm) was monitored using a plate reader.

sections.heading: X-Ray irradiation
sections.text:
Cells were subjected to X-ray irradiation using TR-01 (Techno-X, Osaka, Japan). The type of target in the
irradiator was Tungsten. The tube voltage and the tube current were 80 kVp and 1 mA, respectively. The emitted X-ray was filtered using a 1-mm Aluminium filter. The dose rate was 0.6 Gy/min. Cells (1 x 104) were seeded on
35 mm plastic dishes for 24 h prior to X-ray irradiation. The medium was exchanged with a sample solution prior
to X-ray irradiation after incubation with samples for a specific time at 37 °C. After X-ray irradiation, samples were
immediately removed, and the dishes were refilled with fresh medium.

sections.heading: Clonogenic assay
sections.text:

sections.heading: Cellular internalization of PAA-TiOx NPs
sections.text:
PAA-TiOx NPs were modified with Alexa Fluor 488 hydrazide sodium salt (Thermo Fischer Scientific,
Waltham, MA, USA) and used as a fluorescent probe by mixing at a 20:1 ratio (by weight) with incubation for 1 h
at room temperature. The mixtures were then dialyzed extensively against distilled water overnight at 4 °C to remove the unreacted Alexa Fluor 488 hydrazide. Next, 5 × 104 BxPC3 cells were seeded in 35 and 27 mm
glass-based dishes and incubated for 24 h. The medium was exchanged with fluorescent probe-modified
PAA-TiOx NPs (Fl-PAA-TiOx NPs) at a concentration of 1 mg/ml in PBS. After a specific time interval, cells were washed twice with PBS, and intracellular fluorescence (Ex/Em = 488/505 nm) was assessed using an LSM 5 Pa
laser scanning confocal microscope (LSCM; Carl Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany).

Assay for intracellular H2O2 level
BxPC3 cells (1 x 104) were seeded in a black 96-well plate and incubated for 24 h, after which the medium
was exchanged with PBS containing PAA-TiOx NPs at 1 mg/ml. After a specific time interval, cells were washed once with PBS, and the intracellular H2O2 concentration was measured using a Hydrogen Peroxide Fluorometric Detection Kit with a plate reader (Ex/Em = 490/572 nm).
Results and discussion Adsorption and desorption of H2O2 on the PAA-TiO2 NP surface
PAA-TiO2 NPs and PAA-TiOx NPs used in the current study were synthesized according to a previous
report.[42] First, the basic characteristics of NPs were determined. DLS analysis was used to determine that the dynamic diameters of PAA-TiO2 NPs and PAA-TiOx NPs were 120 and 140 nm, and that their Z-potential was −28 and −30 mV, respectively (Fig. S1A and S1B). TEM observation revealed the detailed topology of the NPs. Primary particles smaller than 10 nm gathered and formed secondary particles that were approximately 50 nm in diameter (Fig. S1C).
The results of our previous study suggest that PAA-TiOx NPs release H2O2 molecules into the liquid
phase of the NP dispersion. In the current study, we characterized the adsorption and desorption properties of
H2O2 on PAA-TiO2 NPs, which were the precursors of PAA-TiOx NPs according to the procedure outlined in Scheme S1. The O2•- adsorbed onto the PAA-TiO2 NPs surface was quantified via ESR spectrometry (Table 1). Since loss of H2O2 from decomposition was not detected throughout this experiment, the total amount of H2O2 adsorbed onto the PAA-TiO2 NPs was 385 µmol/g(particle), which was 38.5% of the input. The amount of H2O2 that was again desorbed into the liquid phase of the dispersion made up 22.2% of the input. The adsorption mode
of the reversibly adsorbed H2O2 was the same as that of the H2O2 that was released from the PAA-TiOx NPs in the previous study. On the other hand, 16.3% of the H2O2 input was not again desorbed from the PAA-TiO2 NP surface for at least 72 h. To additionally investigate the adsorption mode of the irreversibly adsorbed H2O2, the
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
p. 12
amount of O2•- adsorbed on the surface of the PAA-TiO2 NPs was determined. A typical signal of O2•- adsorption on the surface of TiO2 was detected via ESR spectrometry (Fig. S2A). However, the amount of adsorbed H2O2 in the form of O2•- was calculated to be 2.10×10-4% of the input. Since that amount of O2•- was significantly less than the total amount of irreversibly adsorbed H2O2, almost all H2O2 adsorbed on PAA-TiO2 NPs was from another mode of adsorption. We wondered if the difference in the adsorption and desorption rates of H2O2 could be a key to understanding the irreversible adsorption mode of H2O2. The adsorption of H2O2 onto PAA-TiO2 NPs took 72 h to complete (Fig. S2B) while the desorption of H2O2 required only 6 h (Fig. S2C). There existed two different modes in adsorption: fast and slow reactions. One mode would be for reversible adsorption and the other
would be for irreversible adsorption. Another possibility was a reaction in which PAA and H2O2 produced peracids. The amount of H2O2 that contributed to this reaction was negligible because the amount of H2O2 adsorbed onto bare TiO2 NPs was the same as, or greater than, those modified by PAA (data not shown). In any case, investigating the interfacial reaction between nanoparticles and the liquid phase would be difficult, because it
would require the construction of an elaborate analytical system.

p. 13
PAA-TiOx NPs for in vitro experiments were synthesized using a large excess of H2O2 in order to load as
much H2O2 as possible onto the PAA-TiOx NPs. Then, the release of H2O2 from the PAA-TiOx NPs was profiled using the same dialysis method shown in Scheme S1. PAA-TiOx NPs packed in a dialysis tube continued to release H2O2 to the dialysate phase for at least 7 hours, whereas in a H2O2 solution, the H2O2 release finished within 30 min because free H2O2 molecules were able to pass quickly through the dialysis membrane (Fig. 2). That result shows that PAA-TiOx NPs were able to confine H2O2 molecules in the local tissues of the body 14 times longer than what a simple H2O2 solution could accomplish. The PAA-TiOx NPs managed a timed-release of H2O2 sufficient to cover a single radiotherapy session. The H2O2 molecules released from PAA-TiOx NPs, however, were calculated to be 200 µmol/g(NPs), which was the same order as when a lower concentration of
H2O2 was applied to PAA-TiO2 NPs (Table 1). The process of washing PAA-TiOx NPs to remove excess free H2O2 would reduce the amount of H2O2 loaded onto PAA-TiOx NPs. Therefore, in order to synthesize PAA-TiOx NPs with more H2O2 loaded, the primary particle size of raw TiO2 NPs should be reduced to increase the surface area available for adsorption.

sections.heading: Cytotoxicity assay
sections.text:
of
p. 15
The use of PAA-TiOx NPs as H2O2-releasing material raises concerns over potential toxicity. The
cytotoxicity of PAA-TiOx NPs was compared with that of PAA-TiO2 NPs and that of free H2O2 using BxPC3 human pancreatic cancer cells. PAA-modified NPs and H2O2 solution both exhibited dose-dependent toxicity when they were exposed to cells for 24 and 48 h (Fig. 3). After 24 h of exposure, PAA-TiOx NPs, H2O2 solution, and PAA-TiO2 NPs exhibited values for LC50 of 0.895 mg/ml, 341 µM, and 6.60 mg/ml, respectively. The higher toxicity of PAA-TiOx NPs likely was due to the combined toxicity of both PAA-TiO2 NPs and H2O2. Interestingly, treatment with PAA-TiOx NPs for 1 h showed no cytotoxicity whereas the H2O2 solution showed a concentration-dependent toxicity. There was minimal H2O2-derived toxicity detected in cultured cells because the PAA-TiOx NPs did not completely release H2O2 within 1 h.
Figure 2 Cellular toxicity assessments, without X-ray irradiation, for (A) PAA-TiOx NPs, (B) H2O2 solution, and (C) PAA-TiO2 NPs. Cell activities were normalized via the use of a non-treated cell group. Data represent the mean ± STDEV derived from three individual experiments.
Radiosensitizing effect in vitro
A clonogenic assay was performed to assess the radiosensitizing effect of PAA-TiOx NPs. Although an
enhancement of the effect of radiotherapy by PAA-TiOx NPs has already been reported in vitro[41], a more detailed investigation was needed, which included a comparison with H2O2 solutions. Thus, in the following experiments, the concentrations of H2O2 contained in PAA-TiOx NPs and that contained in a H2O2 solution were
Jo ur
na

re -p

adjusted to similar values. First, the radiation dose dependence of the radiosensitizing effect was assessed using
BxPC3 cells. PAA-TiOx NPs and a H2O2 solution of 1 mg/ml and 200 µM, respectively, exhibited a superior radiosensitizing effect by comparison with PBS and PAA-TiO2 NPs (Fig. 3A). Typical photographs of cultured cells irradiated with 5 Gy in the presence of samples apparently reflected the effective radiosensitization of both
PAA-TiOx NPs and a H2O2 solution (Fig. 3B). PAA-TiO2 NPs showed no radiosensitizing effect where TiO2 NPs had been reported to have such an effect.[35] The reason might be that the biochemical effects on the cells were
altered because the particle surfaces were coated by PAA, or that the sample treatment time on the cells prior to
X-ray irradiation was too short.

p. 17
effects of X-ray irradiation while the SF value had generally been used to assess cytotoxicity in clonogenic assay.
The cytotoxicity expressed in terms of SF included two factors: X-ray toxicity and the toxicity of the radiosensitizer
itself. Therefore, the RE value was defined by eliminating the toxicity of the radiosensitizer itself, assuming that
the cytotoxicity is a multiple of these two factors. In brief, the RE value could reveal how many times “the effect of
X-ray irradiation” was multiplied by adopting the radiosensitizer compared with X-ray irradiation only.
The dependence on sample concentration for a radiosensitization effect was evaluated based on the RE
values. As a result, the highest RE values were obtained at concentrations of 1 mg/ml for PAA-TiOx NPs (Fig. 3C) and 200 μM for a H2O2 solution (Fig. 3D), respectively, given that 5 Gy of X-ray irradiation was combined with a sample treatment. The same trend was observed with 3 Gy of X-ray irradiation (Fig. S3). The decrease in RE at
higher concentrations in both samples was due to the high contribution of the radiosensitizer's own toxicity to the
overall level. Radiosensitizers are most therapeutically efficient and least harmful to patients when used at
concentrations that result in the highest RE. Therefore, the PAA-TiOx NPs were used at 1 mg/ml in the following experiments.
PAA-TiOx NP-mediated increase of H2O2 level and radiosensitization of cancer cells
The results above suggest that the radiosensitizing effect of PAA-TiOx NPs was comparable to that of the
H2O2 solution. However, PAA-TiOx NPs had a special capacity for the prolonged release of H2O2 to surroundings. Thus, we hypothesized that PAA-TiOx NPs would be taken up by cancer cells and increase the intracellular H2O2 level. If so, the cells would be more sensitive to X-ray irradiation, with the retention of a high level of H2O2 even in tumor tissue where cells were continuously exposed to, and washed by, a dynamic blood flow.
First, the cellular internalization of PAA-TiOx NPs was confirmed. PAA-TiOx NPs were modified with a fluorescent moiety (Alexa Fluor 488) to form Fl-PAA-TiOx NPs, and fluorescence was monitored using LSCM when
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
p. 18
Fl-PAA-TiOx NPs were applied to cultured cancer cells. As a result, Fl-PAA-TiOx NPs were taken up by BxPC3 cells 10 minutes after administration (Fig. 4A). Then, the intracellular H2O2 level of the BxPC3 cells that had taken up PAA-TiOx NPs was determined using a fluorescent-enzyme conjugated system. The dynamic tumor blood flow that let intracellular H2O2 diffuse to surrounding tissues was modelled by carefully washing the cells with a buffer solution. Despite the buffer wash, PAA-TiOx NPs increased the number and retention of intracellular H2O2 levels more effectively than the H2O2 solution did (Fig. 4B). The increase in intracellular H2O2 level that resulted from the cell internalization of PAA-TiOx NPs was significantly higher than the result of water radiolysis. Finally, the RE
was evaluated for cells with intracellular H2O2 levels that were increased by the uptake of PAA-TiOx NPs. BxPC3 cells were incubated with either PAA-TiOx NPs or a H2O2 solution for 10 minutes, washed once with PBS, and then subjected to X-ray irradiation. Cells treated with PAA-TiOx NPs showed increased radiosensitivity, despite being washed prior to irradiation (Fig. 4C). In contrast, the radiosensitizing effect of H2O2 alone was significantly reduced by a single washing of the cells.
This chapter contains the most important results in this study. As mentioned above, elevated H2O2 levels in
cancer cells enhance radiotherapy, but challenges remained as to how H2O2 could be confined to tumor tissue for long periods of time. To improve the KORTUC, Morita et al. added gelatin or sodium hyaluronate into oxidol.[47]
Song et al. have successfully delivered H2O2 to tumors in vivo and achieved a sustained release of H2O2 by encapsulating it in liposomes, but they have not confirmed a sustained release in cells.[48] The current study is
the first report on the delivery of H2O2 into cancer cells using inorganic nanoparticles and the sustained release of H2O2 in cells. Y. Katsumura calculated that the H2O2 produced by water radiolysis reached a steady state at 0.37 µM within 20 s when X-rays were irradiated in water at a dose rate of 1 Gy/s.[49] Because the dose rate used in
the present study was 0.01-fold that of Katsumura’s report, the H2O2 concentration increased by PAA-TiOx NPs
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
p. 19
would be significantly higher than that increased by water radiolysis during X-ray irradiation to cells (Fig. 4B).
Although this represents the use of a primitive method in vitro, the results clearly prove that the effects of
PAA-TiOx NPs and that of H2O2 solutions on the microenvironment of cancer cells were remarkably different. Furthermore, intracellular H2O2 levels correlated with radiosensitization efficiency (Fig. 4C) provide evidence that a scheme for the direct delivery of H2O2 to targeted cancer cells is effective in improving radiotherapy. However, PAA-TiOx NPs still have some aspects to improve. One is the release control of H2O2. When PAA-TiOx NPs are introduced into the body, they slowly release H2O2 whether in the tumor or not. The other is the poor stealthy nature of PAA-TiOx NPs in the body. Our previous studies have shown that PAA-TiOx NPs are not excreted efficiently and ultimately accumulate in the liver.[50] These problems are directly related to side effects and a risk
of oncogenesis when PAA-TiOx NPs are used as radiosensitizers. Therefore, it is necessary to find solutions such as altering the particle size of TiO2 NPs, searching for polymers to modify the surface, and modifying the surface PAAs with tumor-targeting ligands.[51]

PAA-TiOx NPs. (A) BxPC3 cells took up Fl-PAA-TiOx NPs within 10 minutes. (B) Intracellular H2O2 level increased more with the uptake of PAA-TiOx NPs than with treatment from a H2O2 solution. (C) The radiosensitizing efficiency was markedly raised when the cells were treated with PAA-TiOx NPs for 10 min before an X-ray irradiation of 5 Gy. Data represent the mean ± STDEV derived from three individual experiments. Fl-PAA-TiOx NPs: PAA-TiOx NPs conjugated with fluorescence probe.
Conclusions
The mechanism of PAA-TiOx NPs working as radiosensitizers was partially elucidated in vitro. PAA-TiOx
NPs adsorbed H2O2 during their synthesis process. A portion of the adsorbed H2O2 was released again into the liquid phase of the dispersion, and the remaining portion was not. The release of H2O2 was found to last for at least 7 h, which was sufficient to cover one radiation treatment. PAA-TiOx NPs effectively increased intracellular H2O2 levels by releasing H2O2 even after uptake into cancer cells, resulting in an increase in the radiosensitivity of the cells. These results indicated that PAA-TiOx NPs worked as DDS carriers for the intracellular delivery and sustained release of H2O2. Thus, PAA-TiOx NPs were more effective radiosensitizers than a H2O2 solution, which was highly diffusive to the surrounding tissues. While the findings in this study were advantageous for the use of
PAA-TiOx NPs, it was limited to in vitro cell experimentation using low-energy X-rays (80 kVp). Therefore, an in vivo experiment using a clinical energy X-ray (MV order) will be necessary in order to demonstrate the practical
efficiency and safety of PAA-TiOx NPs in the future.

referenceMentions.context: 4 Introduction Since the discovery of X-rays, radiotherapy has been a widely used addition to surgical resection and chemotherapy in the treatment of cancers.[1,2] Radiotherapy embodies both advantages of the other two major treatment approaches: (i) it has a local therapeutic effect on a tumor, which is similar to surgical resection; and, (ii) it is physically non-invasive, which is similar to chemotherapy.

However, radiotherapy also has various side effects, which also are similar to those of the alternatives.[3,4] Therefore, a number of studies have developed improvements in the therapeutic efficacy of radiotherapy.

Those functionalized TiO2 NPs showed effective radiosensitization in vitro and in vivo and proved that TiO2 NPs could serve as radiosensitizers as well as agents for the delivery of a drug cargo.[36] Polyacrylic acid–modified titanium peroxide (PAA-TiOx) NPs are also considered potential radiosensitizers.

[37–40] In addition, when H2O2 vapor was adsorbed onto the TiO2-surface, subsequent heating of the sample resulted in the release of O2 rather than H2O2 from the gas-solid interface.[37] We previously revealed that PAA-TiOx NPs release H2O2 during the liquid phase of NP dispersion.

In our previous study, the radiosensitizing effect of PAA-TiOx NPs in vivo was investigated in collaboration with clinical radiologists.[41] A local injection of PAA-TiOx NPs into MIAPaCa-2 (human pancreatic cancer cell line) tumors xenografted to nude mice enhanced the therapeutic effect of radiation treatment.

Moreover, subsequent research revealed that the radiosensitizing mechanism for PAA-TiOx NPs differs from that of other inorganic NPs.[42] In our experiments, PAA-TiOx NPs produced either a minimal amount of ROS or none at all in interactions with X-ray irradiation.
